holidays.name: Elephant Appreciation Day
holidays.description: A day dedicated to celebrating and raising awareness about the majestic and intelligent elephants around the world, promoting their protection and conservation.
holidays.origin: Began as part of wildlife protection movements to highlight the threats elephants face, especially from poaching and habitat loss.
holidays.funFact: Elephants are one of the few animals that can recognize themselves in a mirror, showing remarkable self-awareness!

holidays.name: Hobbit Day
holidays.description: Fans of J.R.R. Tolkien’s Middle-earth celebrate the birthdays of Bilbo and Frodo Baggins, the beloved hobbits from "The Lord of the Rings."
holidays.origin: Established by Tolkien enthusiasts who observe both hobbits' birthdays, marked on September 22, as a way to honor Tolkien's legacy.
holidays.funFact: Hobbit Day coincides with the autumnal equinox, symbolizing the change of seasons and new adventures in Middle-earth.

holidays.name: Elephant Polo Day
holidays.description: A quirky sport day where teams play polo on elephants instead of horses, combining tradition with fun and a unique cultural twist.
holidays.origin: Started in the early 20th century in India and Nepal as a novel variation of traditional horse polo.
holidays.funFact: Elephant polo matches usually have mahouts (elephant riders) who skillfully maneuver the animals to help players score!

holidays.name: American Gold Star Mothers Day
holidays.description: A solemn observance recognizing mothers who have lost sons or daughters in military service, honoring their sacrifice and strength.
holidays.origin: Established by the U.S. Congress in 1936 to honor Gold Star mothers who have given their children in service to the country.
holidays.funFact: The 'Gold Star' symbolizes the sacrifice of a family member in military service, originating from World War I traditions.
